**INSTITUTION History & Physical Name: **NAME[AAA, BBB] Acct #: **ID-NUM MRN: **ID-NUM Admitted: **DATE[May 17 2007] Dict: **NAME[WWW, VVV] Attend: **NAME[ZZZ, YYY] Admission history and physical. Date of evaluation, **DATE[May 17 2007]. Clinical location, **INSTITUTION. **INSTITUTION: Right second toe osteomyelitis and diabetic foot ulcer. I have personally seen and examined the patient. Please consider my notes linked to the resident's. I have reviewed her case with Dr. **NAME[UUU TTT], and **NAME[M] am in agreement with the resident's admission history and physical. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Briefly, this is a **AGE[in 70s]-year-old African American female well known to me from my outpatient setting. She has a complicated past medical history that includes established coronary artery disease for which medical management has been implicated, multiple MIs, stent placement, refractory blood pressure, on 4 to 5 antihypertensives. Suboptimally controlled insulin-requiring diabetes mellitus. She had been in her usual state of health until **DATE[Feb 2007] when she noticed a discoloration in her right second toe. She was evaluated for this in the office, and there was no obvious edema or certainly no pain in the area. There was a small break in the skin by **DATE[Apr 2007] without evidence of erythema. It was very superficial. It was thought that it would heal. She has got known peripheral vascular disease. Despite conservative treatment, the right second toe has grown much larger in size. It became painful 4 days ago. The nail itself fell off approximately 3 to 4 weeks ago, and she started to notice a growing ulceration. It has a burning or stinging quality. She is not on anything to make the pain better. It is substantially worse with walking and will actually bleed. She has not noted fever or chills or systemic complaints. She still remains dizzy and is having difficulty with gait disturbance. Recent MRI/MRA showed no evidence of cerebrovascular disease that could be contributing to her dizziness. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Coronary artery disease, followed by Dr. **NAME[SSS]. 2. Resistant or difficult to control hypertension. 3. Renal insufficiency. 4. Diabetes mellitus, insulin requiring. 5. Osteomyelitis of the left great toe. 6. Colon cancer diagnosed in **DATE[Jan 2006], status post colostomy and then colostomy reversal. 7. Appendectomy. 8. History of slightly reduced ejection fraction, longstanding diastolic dysfunction. 9. Cholecystectomy. ALLERGIES: PENICILLIN WHICH CAUSES HIVES. MEDICATIONS: Currently include: 1. Prandin 1 mg with meals. 2. Vytorin **DATE[Feb 21] mg daily. 3. Vasotec 20 mg twice daily. 4. Protonix 40 mg daily. 5. Prandin 1 mg with meals. 6. Plavix 75 mg daily. 7. Magnesium oxide 400 mg daily. 8. Lasix 40 to 60 mg daily depending on fluid and volume status. 9. Lantus insulin. 10. Imdur 60 mg extended release. 11. Catapres patch TTS-3. 12. Atenolol 100 mg twice daily. 13. Aspirin 81 mg daily. 14. Docusate b.i.d. 100 mg. 15. K-Dur 20 mEq daily. SOCIAL HISTORY: She lives with her daughter. She is fairly functional, cognitively intact. No tobacco, no alcohol use. FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: She is discouraged by the vitiligo or hypopigmentation she has developed over the right side of her face. She attributes this to antibiotics. She has had no chest discomfort, no shortness of breath. No nausea, no gastrointestinal complaints. She occasionally gets pain at the surgical site where her colostomy takedown was, but this has been stable through time. Remainder of review of systems is negative. CLINICAL EXAM: Her blood pressure here is 214/107, weight is stable. A tired, fatigued-appearing, elderly African American female in no acute distress. Depressed about the impending admission to the hospital. Her pupils react. Her sclerae are injected. Her oropharynx is clear. Neck is supple. Heart is regular. There is an S4 present and a systolic murmur. Her carotid upstrokes are delayed. She has evidence of hypopigmentation on the right side of her face. It is patchy, and there are several discrete macules extending to the maxillary area. Abdomen is soft. There are normoactive bowel sounds. Her extremities have 1+ edema at the calves. She does have evidence of marked edema and discoloration of the right second toe. There is a clawtoe deformity there. There is an ulcer at the tip of the digit consistent with ischemic ulceration, possibly from poor blood supply. Her peripheral pulse is weak but palpable in the dorsalis pedis range. Posterior tibial is unobtainable. There is slight warmth over the forefoot. IMPRESSION AND PLAN: 1. Right second digit diabetic foot ulcer. Likely arterial ischemia given the degree of pain that she is currently having. Needs to have a semi-urgent evaluation by vascular surgery. We discussed the option of amputation, and she is less than satisfied with this as a treatment modality. We will have Dr. **NAME[RRR] evaluate her as soon as possible to consider IV antibiotic therapy. We will have a PICC line placed and proceed with the next management decision. 2. Difficult to control hypertension. Blood pressure is once again quite high here despite the multidrug regimen that she is on. We will continue to monitor in the inpatient setting. Daughter reports it is normal and have a 24-hour monitor by Dr. **NAME[SSS]'s office that shows markedly improved values over the current ones, so we will continue to monitor, do not change drug therapy at this time. 3. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. Continue Prilosec. 4. Other medical issues stable including diabetes mellitus. Continue outpatient medications. Her last hemoglobin A1c was 8.7. We have tried titrating her medications, and we have run into the problems of hypoglycemia. Keep her on her baseline Lantus, Prandin, and adjust insulin basally as necessary during the inpatient stay. ______________________________ **NAME[VVV WWW], MD HS Job # 786366 / 33115 / SHY # **ID-NUM D: **DATE[May 17 2007] 18:10 T: **DATE[May 17 2007] 18:13
